Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: The Social Dynamics Of Coalescence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines how relationships among individuals can contribute to or undermine the ability of entire groups to act collectively. How and why groups of people come together and achieve common goals is a key question in contemporary social science. In this research, scholars often focus on two ways that people relate with one another: 1) through direct, face-to-face interactions (e.g. conversation, trade); and 2) by sharing an association with the same abstract concept (e.g. identifying as an "American"). When members of a group share both of these types of relations with one another, they are more likely to mobilize to achieve shared goals. To date, scholarship on this topic has focused mostly on how collective action arises in contemporary settings among segments of a larger population that is already socially cohesive in some respects (i.e., social movement within a nation). However, social cohesion develops in many kinds of human societies, and among small or large groups of people. Archaeology is particularly well-suited to make a contribution to this literature because it can offer long term case studies including a variety of human societies that are not represented in contemporary or historical examples. This project focuses on long-term changes in relationships among people in a smaller-scale prehistoric society to provide a new perspective on the development of social cohesion. Such work is essential to understanding how and why social cohesion does (or does not) develop, how and why it is sometimes sustained, and the experiences of people who live through this type of dramatic social change.

This research examines changing individual and group relations during a period of coalescence, a process by which previously separate people or groups come together to form a socially cohesive and long-lasting community. Archaeological data from four Ancestral Wendat (Iroquoian) villages that were successively occupied by the same community over a period of 150 years (1400-1550 C.E.) in what is today Ontario, Canada, provide a long term, intra-community perspective on how social cohesion develops and is sustained. Previous scholarship in this region documents the process of coalescence through changes in village plans from smaller, dispersed communities housing several hundred people to the large, and spatially integrated Mantle site, the culmination of coalescence. This project develops a new approach for studying the development of social cohesion, utilizing a unique theoretical framework to draw new insights from existing, well-established methods. Indicators of the techniques used to produce pottery and pipes provide evidence for direct, interpersonal interactions, while the design and decoration of pottery, pipes, and ornaments reveal abstract, shared connections. Changing individual and group relations among people will be identified within each community by considering the spatial patterns of these characteristics. Differences in these patterns in each sequential community will reveal changing relations among people over the period of coalescence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant supported research for Sarah Striker's dissertation entitled, "The Social Dynamics of Coalescence: Ancestral Wendat Communities ca. 1400-1550 C.E." The project examined how relationships among individuals can contribute to, or undermine, the ability of groups to work together to accomplish shared goals - collective action. How, why, and in what circumstances people work together to accomplish shared goals is an important topic in contemporary social science. To date, most of research in this area has focused on how collective action arises in contemporary or recent historical settings. This study added new insights by examining how these processes worked in an ancient society. Are the social dynamics of collective action different in non-western, pre-industrial settings? How did the experiences of the people who lived through these changes compare to contemporary cases?

Striker selected a sequence of four Ancestral Wendat (Iroquoian) villages that were occupied by the same community of people over a period of 150 years (ca. 1400-1550 C.E.) in present day Ontario, Canada. These villages could provide evidence for how individual and group relationships changed during a period of coalescence, a process of community aggregation that creates a new larger and socially cohesive community. The earliest of these villages were small and dispersed (Pre-Coalescent Period), but through time, the community aggregated, first lacking social cohesion and retaining the former individual-village structure (Coalescent Period), and later on showing social cohesion, when the process of coalescence had been completed and the villages were large and well-integrated (Post-Coalescent Period). Striker's dissertation asked, how did social dynamics change in these communities over time, and how did these dynamics contribute to the social cohesion observed in the well-integrated Post-Coalescent Period village.

To find evidence of how people in these Ancestral Wendat communities related to each other, Striker examined different characteristics of ceramic pottery and pipes from the study sites. Decoration on the pottery can reveal information about the abstract connections that people shared with one another. Differences in clays, tempers, and manner of production of pottery and pipes reveal information about direct connections among the people who made and used these objects. Data on the decoration of pottery was obtained from previous published and unpublished studies. To study production, Striker observed the clays, tempers, and techniques used to construct 1,100 samples of pottery and clay smoking pipes. She was able to identify differences both in the materials and in the production methods the potters and pipe-makers used.

Changes in both decoration and production of pottery and pipes demonstrated a link between the nature of social relations that are shared among community members and their potential to work together as a village unit to achieve common goals. A decrease in the intensity of certain kinds of abstract social connections was observed in the Coalescent Period, when villages first aggregated into a single community. In the Post-Coalescent Period, those abstract social connections become more intensive, extending outside the community and fostering the development of a community scale social identity. These social connections, along with a reorientation of face-to-face social ties, facilitated the development of social cohesion and collective action in the Post-Coalescent Period.

This project has made contributions beyond anthropology and archaeology by examining how community reorganization happened in the past. Specifically, this research shows that the models used to understand the social organization of collective action in large-scale contemporary settings have relevance for small-scale, intra-community archaeological settings as well. The approach developed in this study for examining differences in social dynamics of collective action can be applied in a wide range of other cases, both in archaeology and contemporary or historical settings, to compare different histories of the development of social cohesion among groups. These insights can be applied to contemporary settings to help us understand how social relations contribute to communal outcomes at both a large (national, institutional) and small (community, grassroots) scale, and to inform contemporary policy decisions in response to ongoing social transformations.
